added_lines: import mockfrom keystoneclient import exceptions class FakeClient: class FakeProject: def get(self, project_id): if project_id != 'foo': raise exceptions.NotFound() tenants = FakeProject() projects = FakeProject() self.req = mock.MagicMock() self.controller._get_keystone_client = mock.Mock(return_value=self.FakeClient()) def test_defaults_wrong_tenant_id(self): self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.defaults, self.req, 'boo') def test_show_wrong_tenant_id(self): self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.show, self.req, 'boo') def test_update_wrong_tenant_id(self): body = make_body(gigabytes=20, snapshots=1, volumes=5, backups=5, tenant_id=None) self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.update, self.req, 'boo', body) self.req, 'foo') def test_delete_wrong_tenant_id(self): self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPNotFound, self.controller.delete, self.req, 'boo')

commit_message:
Change default of option volume_driver to LVMVolumeDriver

LVMISCSIDriver is deprecated, LVMVolumeDriver should be used as new
default value for the volume_driver option.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Icee4e3881e4e8f9127fec6238c1e68b1526b553c

commit_message:
Make periodic tasks can run simultaneously

In order to run several magnum-conductor, we should make periodic
tasks can run simultaneously. We should not destroy a bay twice.

Change-Id: I540ba01729543e7b57f322dd28bf11ec555c251d
Partial-Implements: blueprint horizontal-scale

adopt ec2 api to work with keystone v3 api

Change-Id: Ie02ed386da0257c476e34fcd7cc3de818caa584e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/85/209085/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient.v3 import client as keystone_client_v3 is_admin=None, remote_address=None, if 'v3' in CONF.keystone_url: keystone = keystone_client_v3.Client( username=CONF.admin_user, password=CONF.admin_password, project_name=CONF.admin_tenant_name, auth_url=CONF.keystone_url, ) else: keystone = keystone_client.Client( username=CONF.admin_user, password=CONF.admin_password, tenant_name=CONF.admin_tenant_name, auth_url=CONF.keystone_url, )
deleted_lines: is_admin=None, roles=None, remote_address=None, self.roles = roles or [] 'roles': getattr(self, 'roles', None), keystone = keystone_client.Client( username=CONF.admin_user, password=CONF.admin_password, tenant_name=CONF.admin_tenant_name, auth_url=CONF.keystone_url, )

commit_message:
RBD: Reading rbd_default_features from ceph.conf

This patch enables reading rbd_default_features from ceph.conf for rbd
features configuration, falling back to layering if nothing is found.

Closes-Bug: #1480129

Change-Id: I639f06d6375201bdf5d469953bd80644ef433c87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/186537/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kwargs = {'features': client.features}

commit_message:
Fix string/binary conversions for py34 compatibility

Default type of strings in py 2 and 3 are different. So, convert them
explicitly when it is needed for py 2/3 compatibility.

Partially-Implements: bp py3-compatibility
Change-Id: I9b2d7e97fdc7d073a16e729ce0e90b92281fdf8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/13/207813/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import encodeutils def convert_str(text): """Convert to native string. Convert bytes and Unicode strings to native strings: * convert to bytes on Python 2: encode Unicode using encodeutils.safe_encode() * convert to Unicode on Python 3: decode bytes from UTF-8 """ if six.PY2: return encodeutils.safe_encode(text) else: if isinstance(text, bytes): return text.decode('utf-8') else: return text

commit_message:
Update minimum requirement for python-neutronclient

The *_subnetpool(s) calls are available as of python-neutronclient 2.4.0

Needed for Horizon support for Neutron subnet allocation:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/neutron-subnet-allocation
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/203569/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/203570/

Change-Id: I793f0224fe388fc9f90139f541274a54c5609fd1
Implements: blueprint neutron-subnet-allocation

subject: GlusterFS: Using 'fallocate' instead of 'dd'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-15 17:53:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/97515cf7d3a744a83c36c28961dc84d465c0df8b', 'message': "Using 'fallocate' instead of 'dd' to create raw volumes

As 'fallocate' preallocates space to a volume, we can use it to
create raw formatted volume instead of 'dd' command.

This patch also introduces a new configuration parameter in gluster
driver 'glusterfs_fallocate_support', which is set to true when
storage filesystem support 'fallocate' command.

Co-Authored-By: Deepak C Shetty <deepakcs@redhat.com>

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Using 'fallocate' instead of 'dd'

As 'fallocate' preallocates space to a volume, we can use it to
create raw formatted volume instead of 'dd' command.

This patch also introduces a new configuration parameter
'nas_volume_prov_type', which can be set to either 'thin' or 'thick'.

DocImpact
Co-Authored-By: Deepak C Shetty <deepakcs@redhat.com>
Change-Id: If9691b7b9fcb90254d8c108f633aeea4ed4f956d

In run-upgrade.sh we are creating a temporary variables file that is

for the intended purpose - we want to allow containers to talk directly
to the repo containers since users will not be able to configure their
LB ahead of time.

By setting openstack_repo_url, we get the same effect and then we also
need to set the scheme (http://) appropriately so pip-link-build.py

Closes-bug: 1482311

commit_message:
Set the correct variable in run-upgrade.sh

In run-upgrade.sh we are creating a temporary variables file that is
intended to be deleted post upgrade. We were setting the wrong variable
for the intended purpose - we want to allow containers to talk directly
to the repo containers since users will not be able to configure their
LB ahead of time.

By setting openstack_repo_url, we get the same effect and then we also
need to set the scheme (http://) appropriately so pip-link-build.py
appropriately sets up trusted-hosts in pip.conf

Closes-bug: 1482311
Change-Id: I47b2d7aabf669b529f874b1506430e82ad0506e6
(cherry picked from commit 7e27462eed1e7b1ecfc402d56e2041c750f854d2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/03/210603/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Updates chown example of keystone conf file to entire directory

Changes the chown example to set the ownership of /etc/keystone
to both the user and group of keystone. Without this I was seeing
"ERROR: openstack Internal Server Error (HTTP 500)".

Note, when I went through the install I did not need to run an
additional "keystone-manage db_sync" as mentioned in the bug.
That step is documented earlier in the document.

Closes-Bug: #1482134
Change-Id: Ib2a7c07f077fba3a1c43a6f4fbfa671d321f6909
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/89/210189/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

"POT-Creation-Date: 2015-08-08 09:11+0000
" "PO-Revision-Date: 2015-08-10 03:03+0000
"msgid "" "A common way of dealing with the recovery from a full system failure, such " "as a power outage of a data center, is to assign each service a priority, " "and restore in order. <xref linkend="restor-prior-table"/> shows an " "example.<indexterm class="singular"><primary>service restoration</" "primary></indexterm><indexterm class="singular"><primary>maintenance/" "debugging</primary><secondary>complete failures</secondary></indexterm>" msgstr "" "データセンターの電源障害など、完全なシステム障害からリカバリーする一般的な方" "法は、各サービスに優先度を付け、順番に復旧していくことです。<xref linkend=" ""restor-prior-table"/> に例を示します。<indexterm class="singular" ""><primary>service restoration</primary></indexterm><indexterm class=" ""singular"><primary>maintenance/debugging</primary><secondary>complete " "failures</secondary></indexterm>" "As with other architecture decisions, storage concepts within OpenStack " "offer many options. This chapter lays out the choices for you." msgstr "" "他のアーキテクチャーの判断と同じように、OpenStack におけるストレージの概念" "は、さまざまな選択肢があります。この章は選択肢を提示します。" msgid """Because OpenStack is so, well, open, this chapter is dedicated to helping " "you navigate the community and find out where you can help and where you can " "get help." msgstr "" "OpenStack は非常にオープンであるため、この章は、コミュニティーを案内する手助" "けになり、支援したり支援されたりできる場所を見つけることに専念します。" msgid """Because network troubleshooting is especially difficult with virtual " "resources, this chapter is chock-full of helpful tips and tricks for tracing " "network traffic, finding the root cause of networking failures, and " "debugging related services, such as DHCP and DNS." msgstr "" "ネットワークのトラブルシューティングは、仮想リソースでとくに難しくなります。" "この章は、ネットワーク通信の追跡、ネットワーク障害の根本原因の調査、DHCP や " "DNS などの関連サービスのデバッグに関するヒントとコツがたくさん詰まっていま" "す。" msgid """Consider checking for newer versions of the <link xlink:href="https://repos." "fedorapeople.org/repos/openstack/EOL/openstack-havana/">Havana repository</" "link>." msgstr "" "<link xlink:href="https://repos.fedorapeople.org/repos/openstack/EOL/" "openstack-havana/">Havana リポジトリー</link>の新しいバージョンの確認を考慮" "します。" msgid ""msgid "First, save the configuration files on all nodes:" msgstr "まず、すべてのノードの設定ファイルを保存します。" "For the second path, you can write new features and plug them in using " "changes to a configuration file. If the project where your feature would " "need to reside uses the Python Paste framework, you can create middleware " "for it and plug it in through configuration. There may also be specific ways " "of customizing a project, such as creating a new scheduler driver for " "Compute or a custom tab for the dashboard." msgstr "" "2 番目の方法として、新機能を書き、設定ファイルを変更して、それらをプラグイン" "することもできます。もし、あなたの機能が必要とされるプロジェクトが Python " "Paste フレームワークを使っているのであれば、そのための ミドルウェアを作成し、" "環境設定を通じて組み込めばよいのです。例えば、Compute の新しいスケジューラー" "や dashboard のカスタムタブなど、プロジェクトをカスタマイズする
" "を作成するといった、プロジェクトをカスタマイズする具体的な方法もあるかもしれ" "ません。" msgid """If currently present, remove the following key from the [filter:authtoken] " "section in the <filename>/etc/glance/glance-api-paste.ini</filename> and " "<filename>/etc/glance/glance-registry-paste.ini</filename> files:" msgstr "" "まだ存在する場合、<filename>/etc/glance/glance-api-paste.ini</filename> およ" "び <filename>/etc/glance/glance-registry-paste.ini</filename> ファイルの " "[filter:authtoken] セクションから以下のキーを削除します。" msgid ""msgid "Next, back up all databases on the controller:" msgstr "次に、コントローラーのすべてのデータベースをバックアップします。" "On all compute nodes, increase the DHCP lease time (measured in seconds) in " "the <filename>/etc/nova/nova.conf</filename> file to enable currently active " "instances to continue leasing their IP addresses during the upgrade process, " "as follows:" msgstr "" "すべてのコンピュートノードにおいて、以下のように、<filename>/etc/nova/nova." "conf</filename> ファイルの DHCP リース時間 (秒単位) を増やし、動作中のインス" "タンスがアップグレード作業中に IP アドレスを使い続けられるようにします。" msgid ""msgid "" "OpenStack might not do everything you need it to do out of the box. To add a " "new feature, you can follow different paths.<indexterm class="singular" ""><primary>customization</primary><secondary>paths available</secondary></" "indexterm>" msgstr "" "OpenStack はあなたが必要とするすべてのことをしてくれるわけではないかもしれま" "せん。新しい機能を追加するために、いくつかの方法に従うことができます。" "<indexterm class="singular"><primary>customization</" "primary><secondary>paths available</secondary></indexterm>" msgid "" "Remove defunct database configuration from the <filename>/etc/nova/nova." "conf</filename> file:" msgstr "" "消滅したデータベース設定を <filename>/etc/nova/nova.conf</filename> ファイル" "から削除します。" "Several configuration-management tools are available, and this guide does " "not recommend a specific one. The two most popular ones in the OpenStack " "community are <link xlink:href="https://puppetlabs.com/">Puppet</link>, " "with available <link xlink:href="https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-" "openstack">OpenStack Puppet modules</link>; and <link xlink:href="http://" "www.getchef.com/chef/">Chef</link>, with available <link xlink:href=" ""https://github.com/opscode/openstack-chef-repo">OpenStack Chef recipes</" "link>. Other newer configuration tools include <link xlink:href="https://" "juju.ubuntu.com/">Juju</link>, <link xlink:href="http://www.ansible.com/" "home">Ansible</link>, and <link xlink:href="http://www.saltstack.com/" "">Salt</link>; and more mature configuration management tools include <link " "xlink:href="http://cfengine.com/">CFEngine</link> and <link xlink:href=" ""http://bcfg2.org/">Bcfg2</link>." msgstr "" "いくつかの構成管理ツールがあります。このガイドでは特定のものを推奨しません。" "OpenStack コミュニティで人気があるものは <link xlink:href="https://" "puppetlabs.com/">Puppet</link> と <link xlink:href="http://www.getchef.com/" "chef/">Chef</link> の 2 つで、OpenStack 用の設定集がそれぞれ <link xlink:" "href="https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-openstack">OpenStack Puppet " "modules</link> と <link xlink:href="https://github.com/opscode/openstack-" "chef-repo">OpenStack Chef recipes</link> にあります。比較的新しい他のツール" "としては、<link xlink:href="https://juju.ubuntu.com/">Juju</link>、<link " "xlink:href="http://www.ansible.com/home">Ansible</link> や <link xlink:" "href="http://www.saltstack.com/">Salt</link> があります。もう少し成熟した" "ツールとしては <link xlink:href="http://cfengine.com/">CFEngine</link> や " "<link xlink:href="http://bcfg2.org/">Bcfg2</link> があります。" msgid """The cloud controller is an invention for the sake of consolidating and " "describing which services run on which nodes. This chapter discusses " "hardware and network considerations as well as how to design the cloud " "controller for performance and separation of services." msgstr "" "クラウドコントローラーとは、各ノードで実行するサービスを集約して説明するため" "の便宜的なものです。この章は、ハードウェア、ネットワーク、およびパフォーマン" "スとサービスの分離のためにクラウドコントローラーを設定する方法について議論し" "ます。" msgid """The protocol that is matched by the security group rule. Valid values are " "<literal>null</literal>, <literal>tcp</literal>, <literal>udp</literal>, and " "<literal>icmp</literal>." msgstr "" "セキュリティグループのルールに一致するプロトコル。有効な値は、<literal>null</" "literal>、<literal>tcp</literal>、<literal>udp</literal>、<literal>icmp</" "literal> です。" msgid """This chapter describes the compute nodes, which are dedicated to running " "virtual machines. Some hardware choices come into play here, as well as " "logging and networking descriptions." msgstr "" "この章は、仮想マシンを実行するためのコンピュートノードについて記載します。い" "くつかのハードウェアの選択肢があります。ロギングとネットワークについても説明" "しています。" msgid "" "This chapter describes what you need to back up within OpenStack as well as " "best practices for recovering backups." msgstr "" "この章は、OpenStack 中でバックアップする必要があるもの、バックアップのリカバ" "リーのベストプラクティスについて説明します。" msgid "" "This chapter discusses the growth of your cloud resources through scaling " "and segregation considerations." msgstr "" "この章は、規模の拡張および分離における検討を通して、クラウドの拡大について議" "論します。" msgid "" "This chapter goes into the common failures that the authors have seen while " "running clouds in production, including troubleshooting." msgstr "" "この章は、執筆者がこれまで本番環境を運用してきて、トラブルシューティングする" "中で見てきた、一般的な障害について詳細に検討します。" msgid """This chapter is written to let you get your hands wrapped around your " "OpenStack cloud through command-line tools and understanding what is already " "set up in your cloud." msgstr "" "この章は、コマンドラインツールを用いてお使いの OpenStack クラウド全体を理解で" "きるようにするために書かれました。また、お使いのクラウドにすでにセットアップ" "されているものを理解することもできます。" msgid """This chapter provides upgrade information based on the architectures used in " "this book." msgstr "" "この章は、本書で使用されるアーキテクチャーに基づいて、アップグレードに関する" "情報を提供します。" msgid """This chapter shows you where OpenStack places logs and how to best read and " "manage logs for monitoring purposes." msgstr "" "この章は、OpenStack のログ保存場所、監視目的にログを参照および管理する最良の" "方法について説明します。" msgid "" "This chapter walks through user-enabling processes that all admins must face " "to manage users, give them quotas to parcel out resources, and so on." msgstr "" "この章は、すべての管理者がユーザーを管理し、リソースを小さくまとめるクォータ" "を設定するために必ず直面する、ユーザー有効化のプロセスを詳細に説明します。" msgid """To take the first path, you can modify the OpenStack code directly. Learn " "<link xlink:href="https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/How_To_Contribute">how " "to contribute</link>, follow the <link xlink:href="https://wiki.openstack." "org/wiki/GerritWorkflow">code review workflow</link>, make your changes, " "and contribute them back to the upstream OpenStack project. This path is " "recommended if the feature you need requires deep integration with an " "existing project. The community is always open to contributions and welcomes " "new functionality that follows the feature-development guidelines. This path " "still requires you to use DevStack for testing your feature additions, so " "this chapter walks you through the DevStack environment.<indexterm class=" ""singular"><primary>OpenStack community</primary><secondary>customization " "and</secondary></indexterm>" msgstr "" "まず最初に、<link xlink:href="https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/" "How_To_Contribute">貢献方法</link>を学び、<link href="https://wiki." "openstack.org/wiki/GerritWorkflow">Code Review Workflow</link> に従って、あ" "なたの修正をアップストリームの OpenStack プロジェクトへコントリビュートしてく" "ださい。もし、あなたが必要な機能が既存のプロジェクトと密にインテグレーション" "する必要がある場合、これが推奨される選択肢です。コミュニティは、いつでも貢献" "に対して開かれていますし、機能開発ガイドラインに従う新機能を歓迎します。" "<indexterm class="singular"><primary>OpenStack community</" "primary><secondary>customization and</secondary></indexterm>" msgid ""msgid "Upgrade Packages on the Controller Node" msgstr "コントローラーノードのパッケージのアップグレード" "While this book doesn't describe installation, we do recommend automation " "for deployment and configuration, discussed in this chapter." msgstr "" "本書はインストールについて説明していませんが、本章に記載されているように、配" "備と設定を自動化することを強く推奨します。" msgid """Your OpenStack cloud networking needs to fit into your existing networks " "while also enabling the best design for your users and administrators, and " "this chapter gives you in-depth information about networking decisions." msgstr "" "OpenStack クラウドのネットワークは、既存のネットワークに適合する必要がありま" "す。また、ユーザーや管理者にとって最良の設定をできる必要もあります。この章" "は、ネットワークの判断に関する深い情報を提供します。" msgid ""

subject: Implements compare-and-swap instance update
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-27 03:53:46.000000000', 'files': ['nova/exception.py', 'nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fbfb5dd273609aa0a3f387b5a03861d3400bfeae', 'message': 'Implements compare-and-swap instance update

This patch reworks nova.db.sqlalchemy.api._instance_update to remove a
race condition that exists in a critical section of code that retrieves
the instance record from the database, does some checks of both the new
values and existing values of instance fields, and then tries to update
the database with the new values.

Instead of using a SELECT FOR UPDATE, which uses a write-intent lock on
the records that the SELECT statement produces, we instead use an
optimistic compare-and-swap strategy that takes no locks and attempts to
update the instance record while verifying that the record being updated
contains expected values for a set of fields. The algorithm is lock and
obstruction-free, meaning that it allows other threads to make progress,
even other threads that are updating the same instance record in the
database.

To implement the lock-free compare-and-swap algorithm, the previous code
that was relying on the SQLAlchemy ORM and session.add() behaviour was
ripped out and in its place was put a function called
_instance_compare_and_update() that constructs an UPDATE
SQL statement that includes a WHERE condition that has both the instance
UUID primary key, but also the values of other instance fields that
serve to prevent any update to the record unless the record in the
database is what was expected to be in the database at the time instance
validation occurred.

_instance_compare_and_update() returns the number of affected rows from
this UPDATE statement, and callers can check whether the number of
affected rows is zero. If the number of affected rows is zero, that
means another thread updated the instance record in between the time
when the original thread read the record and checked some values from
that record, and the time the original thread went to apply updates to
the database.

If the caller of _instance_compare_and_update() sees no rows were
affected by the attempt to update the database, then the caller proceeds
to grab the instance record from the database (refreshing its known
state) and then re-checking that the fields it wants to update still
meet expected states, and then retries the
_instance_compare_and_update() call.

Change-Id: I7f65ee7af349dbd894a1306d85c696d67a1c7dba
Closes-bug: #1297375
'}]
commit_message:
Implements compare-and-swap instance update

This patch reworks nova.db.sqlalchemy.api._instance_update to remove a
race condition that exists in a critical section of code that retrieves
the instance record from the database, does some checks of both the new
values and existing values of instance fields, and then tries to update
the database with the new values.

Instead of using a SELECT FOR UPDATE, which uses a write-intent lock on
the records that the SELECT statement produces, we instead use an
optimistic compare-and-swap strategy that takes no locks and attempts to
update the instance record while verifying that the record being updated
contains expected values for a set of fields. The algorithm is lock and
obstruction-free, meaning that it allows other threads to make progress,
even other threads that are updating the same instance record in the
database.

To implement the lock-free compare-and-swap algorithm, the previous code
that was relying on the SQLAlchemy ORM and session.add() behaviour was
ripped out and in its place was put a function called
_instance_compare_and_update() that constructs an UPDATE
SQL statement that includes a WHERE condition that has both the instance
UUID primary key, but also the values of other instance fields that
serve to prevent any update to the record unless the record in the
database is what was expected to be in the database at the time instance
validation occurred.

_instance_compare_and_update() returns the number of affected rows from
this UPDATE statement, and callers can check whether the number of
affected rows is zero. If the number of affected rows is zero, that
means another thread updated the instance record in between the time
when the original thread read the record and checked some values from
that record, and the time the original thread went to apply updates to
the database.

If the caller of _instance_compare_and_update() sees no rows were
affected by the attempt to update the database, then the caller proceeds
to grab the instance record from the database (refreshing its known
state) and then re-checking that the fields it wants to update still
meet expected states, and then retries the
_instance_compare_and_update() call.

Change-Id: I7f65ee7af349dbd894a1306d85c696d67a1c7dba
Closes-bug: #1297375
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/109837/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check_instance_update(context, session, instance_ref, expected_task_states=None, expected_vm_states=None, new_hostname=None): """Checks that instance in DB is in expected state before our update. Helper method to check that values of what we're going to update an instance to meet some expectations on the state of the instance right before we update the database. :param instance_ref: The existing instance from the database :param expected_task_states: Either None, or an iterable of task states that the existing database instance may be in to pass the check. :param expected_vm_states: Either None, or an iterable of VM states that the existing database instance may be in to pass the check. :param new_hostname: The new hostname to set the instance to, or None if not changing hostname. :raises - UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError, UnexpectedTaskStateError, UnexpectedVMStateError when the existing instance does not meet the set of supplied expected task or VM states - InstanceExists when new hostname would not be unique """ actual_state = instance_ref["task_state"] if expected_task_states is not None: if actual_state not in expected_task_states: if actual_state == task_states.DELETING: raise exception.UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError( actual=actual_state, expected=expected_task_states) else: raise exception.UnexpectedTaskStateError( actual=actual_state, expected=expected_task_states) actual_state = instance_ref["vm_state"] if expected_vm_states is not None: if actual_state not in expected_vm_states: raise exception.UnexpectedVMStateError(actual=actual_state, expected=expected_vm_states) if new_hostname is not None: instance_hostname = instance_ref['hostname'] or '' if new_hostname.lower() != instance_hostname.lower(): _validate_unique_server_name(context, session, new_hostname) def _fetch_and_check_instance(context, session, instance_uuid, columns_to_join, expected_task_states=None, expected_vm_states=None, new_hostname=None): instance_ref = _instance_get_by_uuid(context, instance_uuid, session=session, columns_to_join=columns_to_join) _check_instance_update(context, session, instance_ref, expected_task_states=expected_task_states, expected_vm_states=expected_vm_states, new_hostname=new_hostname) # The expected values are field/value combinations that we expect to # find in the current instance record in the database. expected_values = { 'task_state': instance_ref['task_state'], 'vm_state': instance_ref['vm_state'], 'hostname': instance_ref['hostname'] } return instance_ref, expected_values def _instance_compare_and_update(session, instance_uuid, values, expected_values): """Attempts to update the instance record in the database. Constructs a raw UPDATE SQL statement, with a WHERE condition that contains not only the instance UUID, but also a collection of expected field/value combinations. The function returns the number of records that were affected by the UPDATE statement, so this can be used to implement a SQL-based compare-and-swap loop, where the caller attempts to update the database record for the instance, but only update the record if the existing record matches precisely what the caller expects. The alternative to this is to use the lock-heavy SELECT FOR UPDATE. :param session: DB session to grab a connection from. :param instance_uuid: UUID of the instance to attempt an update for. :param values: The new field values to set. :param expected_values: The old values for some fields that we expect to be in the current record, otherwise we don't do the update. :returns The number of records that were affected by the UPDATE statement """ if not values: LOG.debug("Attempted to update an instance with no new values.") return 1 conn = session.connection() inst_tab = models.Instance.__table__ where_conds = [inst_tab.c.uuid == instance_uuid] for field, value in expected_values.items(): where_conds.append(inst_tab.c[field] == value) upd_stmt = inst_tab.update().where(and_(*where_conds)).values(**values) res = conn.execute(upd_stmt) return res.rowcount # Determine if we expect specific task or VM states for the # existing instance in the database. Note that an # expected_task_state of None is not the same as an # expected_task_state of [None]. The former means there is no # expectation, while the latter means that there is an expectation # that the task_state is None (i.e. there is no currently-running # task against the instance) expected_task_states = values.pop("expected_task_state", None) if expected_task_states is not None: if not isinstance(expected_task_states, (tuple, list, set)): expected_task_states = (expected_task_states,) expected_vm_states = values.pop("expected_vm_state", None) if expected_vm_states is not None: if not isinstance(expected_vm_states, (tuple, list, set)): expected_vm_states = (expected_vm_states,) new_hostname = values.get("hostname") _handle_objects_related_type_conversions(values) metadata = values.pop('metadata', None) system_metadata = values.pop('system_metadata', None) session = get_session() # Here, we avoid a race condition in between checking expected # states and updating the database by using a compare and swap # loop that constructs an UPDATE statement with a WHERE condition # that contains the field values of the fields of the instance_ref # retrieved above. If the UPDATE statement fails to return a non-zero # number of rows affected, then we retrieve the current database # record again and retry the UPDATE statement after checking the # refreshed instance state still meets our expectations. # # Note that we use this technique here instead of holding a write # intent lock on the instance in the database using SELECT FOR UPDATE. instance_ref, expected_values = _fetch_and_check_instance( context, session, instance_uuid, columns_to_join, expected_task_states=expected_task_states, expected_vm_states=expected_vm_states, new_hostname=new_hostname) updated = _instance_compare_and_update(session, instance_uuid, values, expected_values) attempts = 1 max_time = time.time() + 10 base_interval = 0.05 multiplier = 1 while updated < 1: if time.time() < max_time: # Figure out an exponential backoff interval... interval = base_interval * (2 ** multiplier) time.sleep(interval) multiplier += 1 else: # NOTE(jaypipes): Note that this really should not happen, since # if another thread updated the instance, we either will # refresh the instance_ref and retry our check logic, and do # our update, or the refreshed instance_ref's states will fail # the checks, and we'll raise an exception out of this retry # block. But, just in case, I've put in a failsafe here just in # case, along with an informative error message that at least # gives us some modicum of data with which to figure out what # conditions may have caused an update storm. msg = _("We've attempted %(attempts)d tries to update instance " "%(uuid)s, expecting existing field values of " "%(expected_values)s and new values of %(values)s. " "However, one or more other threads have been able to " "update the same instance in between attempts and " "refreshing the instance's existing state.") LOG.error(msg, dict(uuid=instance_uuid, attempts=attempts, expected_values=expected_values, values=values)) raise exception.InstanceUpdateTimeout() instance_ref, expected_values = _fetch_and_check_instance( context, session, instance_uuid, columns_to_join, expected_task_states=expected_task_states, expected_vm_states=expected_vm_states, new_hostname=new_hostname) msg = ("Failed to update instance %(uuid)s. Another thread updated " "the instance in between the time the instance record was " "fetched in this thread and the time we attempted to update " "the instance. This is attempt %(attempts)d at a retry of our " "instance update.") LOG.debug(msg, dict(uuid=instance_uuid, attempts=attempts)) attempts += 1 updated = _instance_compare_and_update(session, instance_uuid, values, expected_values) if copy_old_instance: old_instance_ref = copy.copy(instance_ref) else: old_instance_ref = None # Even though we've already save the updated values above, we still # want to return the updated instance_ref to the caller... instance_ref.update(values) with session.begin(): metadata, system_metadata,
deleted_lines: session = get_session() with session.begin(): instance_ref = _instance_get_by_uuid(context, instance_uuid, session=session, columns_to_join=columns_to_join) if "expected_task_state" in values: # it is not a db column so always pop out expected = values.pop("expected_task_state") if not isinstance(expected, (tuple, list, set)): expected = (expected,) actual_state = instance_ref["task_state"] if actual_state not in expected: if actual_state == task_states.DELETING: raise exception.UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError( actual=actual_state, expected=expected) else: raise exception.UnexpectedTaskStateError( actual=actual_state, expected=expected) if "expected_vm_state" in values: expected = values.pop("expected_vm_state") if not isinstance(expected, (tuple, list, set)): expected = (expected,) actual_state = instance_ref["vm_state"] if actual_state not in expected: raise exception.UnexpectedVMStateError(actual=actual_state, expected=expected) instance_hostname = instance_ref['hostname'] or '' if ("hostname" in values and values["hostname"].lower() != instance_hostname.lower()): _validate_unique_server_name(context, session, values['hostname']) if copy_old_instance: old_instance_ref = copy.copy(instance_ref) else: old_instance_ref = None metadata = values.get('metadata') values.pop('metadata'), system_metadata = values.get('system_metadata') values.pop('system_metadata'), _handle_objects_related_type_conversions(values) instance_ref.update(values) session.add(instance_ref)

commit_message:
Update plugin documentation

Several projects have begun to make OSC plugins; we should list
the status of the major projects, so users can know if they
can expect support for that feature/project.

Change-Id: Ib3c11c8f2b90663e37578a2714d438944eb1c6f6

correct image/snapshot to do restore.

commit_message:
Fix restore point if backup base is diff-format in ceph

In Ceph when backup base is diff-format and use this backup
to restore volumes not rbd, need to find out the correct restore
point.

This is fixed in cinder/backup/drivers/ceph.py _diff_restore_allowed.

Before the change: when backup is diff-format, and destination volume
is not rbd, the function returns restore_point as None. As a result,
backup restore uses wrong image/snapshot to do restore.

With the change, we always get the right restore point, regardless
of the kind of restore we'll do differential or not.

Change-Id: I006c05d246f59fc6aff597543bedc68589d37576
Closes-Bug: #1472088

commit_message:
docs: add link to liberty summit session on v2.1 API

Whenever someone asks about v2 vs v2.1 vs v3 API and I point
to the docs, I also point to the Liberty summit session which
is good for new people to watch before trying to sort through
the docs and code, so add a link to the high-level section
of the docs.

Change-Id: I34d734454afcfdae3f874160dfd11662e61c2faa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/210587/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use DeferredOVSBridge in setup_default_table

setup_default_table method in br-tun module fires multiple ofctl
calls. Using DeferredOVSBridge will help us save us few calls to OVS.

Closes-Bug: #1259847

Change-Id: Ide7c91ebcd5ad9690c7892b30d8645d88ba324cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/41/210841/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with self.deferred() as deferred_br: deferred_br.add_flow(priority=1, in_port=patch_int_ofport, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN) deferred_br.add_flow(priority=0, actions="drop") if arp_responder_enabled: # ARP broadcast-ed request go to the local ARP_RESPONDER # table to be locally resolved # REVISIT(yamamoto): arp_op=arp.ARP_REQUEST deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=1, proto='arp', dl_dst="ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff", actions=("resubmit(,%s)" % constants.ARP_RESPONDER)) # PATCH_LV_TO_TUN table will handle packets coming from patch_int # unicasts go to table UCAST_TO_TUN where remote addresses are # learnt deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=0, dl_dst="00:00:00:00:00:00/01:00:00:00:00:00", actions=("resubmit(,%s)" % constants.UCAST_TO_TUN)) # Broadcasts/multicasts go to table FLOOD_TO_TUN that handles # flooding deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=0, dl_dst="01:00:00:00:00:00/01:00:00:00:00:00", actions=("resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN)) # Tables [tunnel_type]_TUN_TO_LV will set lvid depending on tun_id # for each tunnel type, and resubmit to table LEARN_FROM_TUN where # remote mac addresses will be learnt for tunnel_type in constants.TUNNEL_NETWORK_TYPES: deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.TUN_TABLE[tunnel_type], priority=0, actions="drop") # LEARN_FROM_TUN table will have a single flow using a learn action # to dynamically set-up flows in UCAST_TO_TUN corresponding to # remote mac addresses (assumes that lvid has already been set by # a previous flow) learned_flow = ("table=%s," "priority=1," "hard_timeout=300," "NXM_OF_VLAN_TCI[0..11]," "NXM_OF_ETH_DST[]=NXM_OF_ETH_SRC[]," "load:0->NXM_OF_VLAN_TCI[]," "load:NXM_NX_TUN_ID[]->NXM_NX_TUN_ID[]," "output:NXM_OF_IN_PORT[]" % constants.UCAST_TO_TUN) # Once remote mac addresses are learnt, output packet to patch_int deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.LEARN_FROM_TUN, priority=1, actions="learn(%s),output:%s" % (learned_flow, patch_int_ofport)) # Egress unicast will be handled in table UCAST_TO_TUN, where # remote mac addresses will be learned. For now, just add a # default flow that will resubmit unknown unicasts to table # FLOOD_TO_TUN to treat them as broadcasts/multicasts deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.UCAST_TO_TUN, priority=0, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN) if arp_responder_enabled: # If none of the ARP entries correspond to the requested IP, # the broadcast-ed packet is resubmitted to the flooding table deferred_br.add_flow(table=constants.ARP_RESPONDER, priority=0, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN)
deleted_lines: self.add_flow(priority=1, in_port=patch_int_ofport, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN) self.add_flow(priority=0, actions="drop") if arp_responder_enabled: # ARP broadcast-ed request go to the local ARP_RESPONDER table to # be locally resolved # REVISIT(yamamoto): arp_op=arp.ARP_REQUEST self.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=1, proto='arp', dl_dst="ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff", actions=("resubmit(,%s)" % constants.ARP_RESPONDER)) # PATCH_LV_TO_TUN table will handle packets coming from patch_int # unicasts go to table UCAST_TO_TUN where remote addresses are learnt self.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=0, dl_dst="00:00:00:00:00:00/01:00:00:00:00:00", actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.UCAST_TO_TUN) # Broadcasts/multicasts go to table FLOOD_TO_TUN that handles flooding self.add_flow(table=constants.PATCH_LV_TO_TUN, priority=0, dl_dst="01:00:00:00:00:00/01:00:00:00:00:00", actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN) # Tables [tunnel_type]_TUN_TO_LV will set lvid depending on tun_id # for each tunnel type, and resubmit to table LEARN_FROM_TUN where # remote mac addresses will be learnt for tunnel_type in constants.TUNNEL_NETWORK_TYPES: self.add_flow(table=constants.TUN_TABLE[tunnel_type], priority=0, actions="drop") # LEARN_FROM_TUN table will have a single flow using a learn action to # dynamically set-up flows in UCAST_TO_TUN corresponding to remote mac # addresses (assumes that lvid has already been set by a previous flow) learned_flow = ("table=%s," "priority=1," "hard_timeout=300," "NXM_OF_VLAN_TCI[0..11]," "NXM_OF_ETH_DST[]=NXM_OF_ETH_SRC[]," "load:0->NXM_OF_VLAN_TCI[]," "load:NXM_NX_TUN_ID[]->NXM_NX_TUN_ID[]," "output:NXM_OF_IN_PORT[]" % constants.UCAST_TO_TUN) # Once remote mac addresses are learnt, output packet to patch_int self.add_flow(table=constants.LEARN_FROM_TUN, priority=1, actions="learn(%s),output:%s" % (learned_flow, patch_int_ofport)) # Egress unicast will be handled in table UCAST_TO_TUN, where remote # mac addresses will be learned. For now, just add a default flow that # will resubmit unknown unicasts to table FLOOD_TO_TUN to treat them # as broadcasts/multicasts self.add_flow(table=constants.UCAST_TO_TUN, priority=0, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN) if arp_responder_enabled: # If none of the ARP entries correspond to the requested IP, the # broadcast-ed packet is resubmitted to the flooding table self.add_flow(table=constants.ARP_RESPONDER, priority=0, actions="resubmit(,%s)" % constants.FLOOD_TO_TUN)

commit_message:
Fix volume limit exceeded exception

The VolumeLimitExceeded exception contains the wrong limit when
the number of volumes exceeds the quota corresponding to a volume
type. It always contains the limit of quota 'volumes'. This patch
fixes the limit in both exception and log message. It also adds
the quota name to exception and log message for better clarity.

Change-Id: I3e2d4fa00fe49f64b2153930e901fccd8015483e
Closes-Bug: #1481182

commit_message:
Enable os.senlin.test profile type for functional test

We will use this profile type in some functional test cases where
the interaction between Senlin and other services does not need to
be verified.

Change-Id: Idfad647385012056fcfc32331c5ba3464f77765f

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/25/197825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from heat_integrationtests.common import test test_vol_type_encryption = { 'heat_template_version': '2015-04-30', 'description': 'Test template to create volume type encryption.', 'resources': { 'my_volume_type': { 'type': 'OS::Cinder::VolumeType', 'properties': { 'name': 'LUKS' } }, 'my_encrypted_vol_type': { 'type': 'OS::Cinder::EncryptedVolumeType', 'properties': { 'provider': 'nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor', 'control_location': 'front-end', 'cipher': 'aes-xts-plain64', 'key_size': 512, 'volume_type': {'get_resource': 'my_volume_type'} } } } } class CreateVolTypeEncryption(test.HeatIntegrationTest): def setUp(self): super(CreateVolTypeEncryption, self).setUp() self.client = self.orchestration_client def test_create_update(self): vt = 'my_volume_type' e_vt = 'my_encrypted_vol_type' stack_identifier = self.stack_create( template=test_vol_type_encryption, expected_status='CREATE_COMPLETE', disable_rollback=True) # check if only two resources are created. expected_resources = {vt: 'OS::Cinder::VolumeType', e_vt: 'OS::Cinder::EncryptedVolumeType'} self.assertEqual(expected_resources, self.list_resources(stack_identifier)) vt_obj = self.client.resources.get(stack_identifier, vt) e_vt_obj = self.client.resources.get(stack_identifier, e_vt) # check if encryption specs are created as desired. specs = self.volume_client.volume_encryption_types.get( e_vt_obj.physical_resource_id) self.assertEqual(512, specs.key_size) self.assertEqual('nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor', specs.provider) self.assertEqual('aes-xts-plain64', specs.cipher) self.assertEqual('front-end', specs.control_location) # Change some properties and trigger update. my_encrypted_vol_type = test_vol_type_encryption[ 'resources']['my_encrypted_vol_type'] my_encrypted_vol_type['properties']['key_size'] = 256 my_encrypted_vol_type['properties']['cipher'] = 'aes-cbc-essiv' self.update_stack(stack_identifier, test_vol_type_encryption) self.assertEqual(expected_resources, self.list_resources(stack_identifier)) vt_obj_updated = self.client.resources.get(stack_identifier, vt) e_vt_obj_updated = self.client.resources.get(stack_identifier, e_vt) # check if phy_rsrc_id are same before and after update. self.assertEqual(vt_obj.physical_resource_id, vt_obj_updated.physical_resource_id) self.assertEqual(e_vt_obj.physical_resource_id, e_vt_obj_updated.physical_resource_id) # ensure that only key_size & cipher are changed after update. specs = self.volume_client.volume_encryption_types.get( e_vt_obj_updated.physical_resource_id) self.assertEqual(256, specs.key_size) self.assertEqual('nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor', specs.provider) self.assertEqual('aes-cbc-essiv', specs.cipher) self.assertEqual('front-end', specs.control_location)

commit_message:
Bump monotonic to 0.3

The version 0.1 of monotonic did not support Solaris. The fix was merged
in version 0.3, so we can remove exception catching around import
monotonic for oslo.utils in oslo_utils/timeutils.py.

Related review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/210486/

Change-Id: Ia3d4b01b665c8d97161164c89b1c92a5eb61d5b2
Related-Bug: 1476588

commit_message:
refactoring update_task

Function update_task will be too complex if we add another exception inside,
but this is required by bug 1475057.
Require small refactoring.
Change-Id: Idec60343b2b859b466514400de9bb1ce22879d96
Partial-Bug: #1475057

added_lines: self._message_parser(message) self.status_reason = 'Stack %s completed successfully' % action self.status = self.COMPLETE self.status = self.FAILED self.status_reason = 'Timed out' except ForcedCancel as e: if self._update_exception_handler( exc=e, action=action, update_task=update_task, force_cancel=True): yield self.update_task(oldstack, action=self.ROLLBACK) return except ForcedCancelWithRollback as e: if self._update_exception_handler( exc=e, action=action, update_task=update_task, force_rollback=True, force_cancel=True): # If rollback is enabled, we do another update, with the # existing template, so we roll back to the original state if self._update_exception_handler( exc=e, action=action, update_task=update_task): yield self.update_task(oldstack, action=self.ROLLBACK) return def _update_exception_handler(self, exc, action, update_task, force_rollback=False, force_cancel=False): require_rollback = False self.status_reason = six.text_type(exc) self.status = self.FAILED if action == self.UPDATE: if force_cancel: update_task.updater.cancel_all() if force_rollback or not self.disable_rollback: require_rollback = True return require_rollback def _message_parser(self, message): if message == rpc_api.THREAD_CANCEL: raise ForcedCancel() elif message == rpc_api.THREAD_CANCEL_WITH_ROLLBACK: raise ForcedCancelWithRollback()

commit_message:
Add cloud_backend_name option into Senlin config

This option is used to define the default cloud backend that Senlin
will talk with to create real resources.

Partially implement: blueprint reimplement-senlin-drivers-as-plugin
Change-Id: I4e1c4a8e43dcb48fb028fa3066a7aed434579f9a

commit_message:
Convergence: Implementation of timeout

The resource provisioning work is distributed among heat engines, so the
timeout also has to be distributed and brought to the resource level
granularity.

Thus,
1. Before invoking check_resource on a resource, ensure that the stack
has not timed out.
2. Pass the remaining amount of time to the resource converge method so
that it can raise timeout exception if it cannot finish in the remaining
time.

Once timeout exception is raised by a resource converge method, the
corresponding stack is marked as FAILED with "Timed out" as failure
reason. Then, if rollback is enabled on the stack, it is triggered.

Change-Id: Id1806d546c67505137f57f72d5b463dc229a666d

commit_message:
Add config entries to skip integration tests

This adds options to skip scenario and functional tests.
You can either skip the complete set of tests or list of specific
tests.

Following new config options are added:

`skip_scenario_tests` -  Skip all scenario tests
`skip_functional_tests` - Skip all functional tests
`skip_functional_test_list` - List of functional tests to skip
`skip_scenario_test_list` - List of scenario tests to skip
`skip_test_stack_action_list` - List of actions in tests to skip

Change-Id: I7a5233f5db1f065ccee5a97408c72203c108a656
Depends-On: I25c5e853f0499b88f2803b077d19e132140908f1

when process of managing existing is finished.

subject: Move update_migrated_volume() to BaseVD
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-06 14:01:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/c9a8cfe1f0492941e854153dfe260bd09de04aeb', 'message': 'Fix update_migrate_volume() exception handling

The update_migrated_volume() function on volume/manager.py calls the
update_migrated_volume() from the driver. If the driver does not implement the
function, the manager falls back (by catching the NotImplementedError
exception) and implements a default behavior, not renaming the volume.

If the driver does not have the function implemented, the migration will fail
as in this case, an AttributeError exception can be raised.

Change-Id: I9f3cbdc5ae1cdcbf8fe61168abf35b985d4182c6
Closes-bug: #1471807
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-07 17:17:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/cfc91946a25df214bac7413655b74e33c3620e1b', 'message': 'Fix update_migrate_volume() exception handling

function, the manager falls back (by catching the NotImplementedError
exception) and implements a default behavior, not renaming the volume.
If the driver does not have the function implemented, the migration will fail
as in this case, an AttributeError exception can be raised.

We fix this by implementing the funcion update_migrate_volume() in the BaseVD
driver so all drivers now throw the proper exception.

commit_message:
Move update_migrated_volume() to BaseVD

The update_migrated_volume() function on volume/manager.py
calls the update_migrated_volume() from the driver. If the
driver does not implement the function, the manager falls
back (by catching the NotImplementedError exception) and
implements a default behavior, not renaming the volume.  If
the driver does not have the function implemented, the
migration will fail as in this case, an AttributeError
exception can be raised.

We fix this by implementing the method
update_migrate_volume() in the BaseVD driver so all drivers
now throw the proper exception.

Change-Id: I9f3cbdc5ae1cdcbf8fe61168abf35b985d4182c6
Closes-Bug: #1471807

commit_message:
Port Tintri driver to ABC driver model

The Tintri driver implements methods for some abstract classes not
inherited with NfsDriver. This patch makes the driver inherit from all
the classes that it implements.

Change-Id: I36c3ac5368e99e367e6541cec8198fa475f1dffe
Partially-implements: blueprint abc-driver-update

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 issues in Hitachi HNAS tests

* Replace __builtin__ with six.moves.builtins.
* Replace tempfile.mkstemp() with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile() to get a
  text file instead of a binary file.
* tox.ini: add the following tests to Python 3.4

  - cinder.tests.unit.test_hitachi_hnas_backend
  - cinder.tests.unit.test_hitachi_hnas_iscsi
  - cinder.tests.unit.test_hitachi_hnas_nfs

Blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: I9a26b4e67033a443271e8f13bcaea5e122ec865a

Port remotefs driver to Python 3

* When parsing share configuration: replace "\040" with a space
  explicitly instead of using the Python unicode_escape encoding:
  see the bug #1180984.
* Encode Unicode to UTF-8 before hash it with MD5.
* tox.ini: add cinder.tests.unit.test_glusterfs to Python 3.4

Blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: Iea943a1f2dfb050fe43ff41411e258adb3f3b6d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/75/197075/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six share_address = share_info[0].strip() if six.PY2: share_address = share_address.decode('unicode_escape') if isinstance(base_str, six.text_type): base_str = base_str.encode('utf-8')

Port IBM driver to Python 3

* Replace map(None, it1, it2) with zip(it1, it2)
* tox.ini: add the following tests to Python 3.4

  - cinder.tests.unit.test_ibm_flashsystem_iscsi
  - cinder.tests.unit.test_ibmnas

This patch requires Python 3 fixes in os-brick.

Blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: I735c39e08cf6e4edd06cf07243fe798b65e8c1a5

commit_message:
Fix url regexp to proceed oslo-specific url's properly

The current url_re regexp ignores dots in egg section, so it proceeds
url with "#egg=oslo.messaging" as "#egg=oslo". This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ifcea3e825218578f799c0a951baac8f8e8ef5de5

commit_message:
Require pbr>1.4.0

pbr 1.4.0 was released 2015-08-03 and includes a feature to
support wsgi_scripts creation. Keystone could use this for
creating the "admin" and "main" wsgi scripts.

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbr/

commit_message:
Spec for Architecture Design Guide improvements

Change-Id: Ie1d2ececd9078f34e7ae868013cc08af6b14f811
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/docs-specs refs/changes/25/209325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Architecture Design Guide Improvements ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/arch-guide Review, edit, and reorganize the Architecture Design Guide. Problem description =================== The Architecture Design Guide has not been thoroughly reviewed since its creation. This has led to the following issues: - language and syntax not in accordance with our conventions - improvable information architecture - duplication of content Proposed change =============== - Reorganize guides to improve presentation of existing content - Clean up existing content where necessary and remove duplication - Identify information gaps and raise bugs where necessary This work is a precursor to converting this guide from Docbook XML to RST in a future release. Alternatives ------------ - Leave the guide as it is - raise bugs against each individual section that requires improvement Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Brian Moss (bmoss) Other contributors: Documentation Swarm attendees Work Items ---------- The bulk of this work is expected to be completed at the upcoming documentation swarm taking place in Brisbane AU on August 13-14. See :ref:`References`. - Rework the abstract to clearly identify the audience and purpose of the book - Reduce duplication in the guide as much as possible. - Edit for consistency and adherence to our conventions - Move sections as required to improve information architecture Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Standard documentation review process. .. _References: References ========== `Documentation Conventions <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Conventions>`_ `Swarm Website <http://openstack-swarm.rhcloud.com/>`_

commit_message:
Add pyroute2 (python netlink bindings)

Useful for all things Linux/kernel/networking related - Neutron and
Octavia are the first 2 projects lining up to use it.

pyroute2 is the most comprehensive NETLINK library on pypy, actively
maintained, Py3 compatible, and GPL2/Apache2.  The code looks good
enough to depend on to me.

Note pyroute2 0.3.6 release has been dual licensed GPL2/Apache2 (either
license, at your choice) - earlier versions were GPL2 only.

Distro status at time of writing:
Fedora: contains python-pyroute2 0.3.4
Debian/Ubuntu: contains python{,3}-pyroute2 0.3.5

Change-Id: Id647a4f509285c873cc32dbb5dcdecc124df29ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/64/168764/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pyroute2>=0.3.6 # Apache-2.0 (+ dual licensed GPL2)

commit_message:
Use Heat resource to validate resource_type_show

Patch I01aaadf86bf86f2a01bfd3fd28541522ef5a99cf added new functionality,
which raise error, if resource related endpoint is not registred in
keystone. Due to heatclient functional tests job starts only heat and
keystone service, we should use Heat resources for testing. The good
candidate for it is OS::Heat::RandomString.

Change-Id: I274a6db5c886ce8e19968e6e2ae8b16e93315cb7
Closes-Bug: #1482661

commit_message:
Make AccessInfo a dictionary

Whilst I did try to avoid this in keystoneauth it just makes it
difficult to properly reuse it from keystoneclient.

Make the AccessInfo object a dictionary of the token data however make
sure it doesn't include the extra crap that keystoneclient had.

Some other small fixes that bring it into like with that from
keystoneclient.

Change-Id: I3af39ba2d3fd45a1b0f1340fc39d65217835ed56

commit_message:
Use networkx 1.10

The networkx graph library released 1.10 which includes features
taskflow (and likely others) would like to take advantage of,
such as ordered digraphs (which retain there node/edge addition
order).

Change-Id: Ib30c70dddeba6c4d16b8cf4dab9caddbdd1664d5

commit_message:
Added X509KeyPair object and data model.

This patch adds backend object and data model to handle x509keypair
related operations.

Partially-Implements: bp secure-kubernetes

Change-Id: I862dcdd10d28b3d5e5f972c7c23bdab6c188a04d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/01/203901/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class CertNotFound(ResourceNotFound): message = _("Cert %(cert)s could not be found.") class CertAlreadyExists(Conflict): message = _("A cert with UUID %(uuid)s already exists.")

subject: Bump some python-*client to avoid oslo.utils
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-02 10:11:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/15540f4e39305cb728bd43113b85ad8d6b1bf4d2', 'message': 'Bump troveclient to 1.2.0

The old version 1.0.9 of troveclient is still using the oslo.utils
namespaced calls, which are now gone from the min oslo.utils we
require. So effectively, we need a higher version of troveclient.

Change-Id: Ia2ebec1b54d51b571897e42c63bd0f7b71006579
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-03 12:30:51.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/a602dae7f52dd12ef8b1a37ffcabfb304a3f2a74', 'message': "Bump some python-*client to avoid oslo.utils

Some old clients are still using oslo.utils namespaced calls.
Since we're now gating with newer version of oslo.utils, this
make some server package fails, so we need to bump versions of
some clients.

This update fixes the minimum version for:
- troveclient
- novaclient
- neutronclient

There may be some others to update as well.

Change-Id: Ia2ebec1b54d51b571897e42c63bd0f7b71006579
"}]
commit_message:
Bump some python-*client to avoid oslo.utils

Some old clients are still using oslo.utils namespaced calls.
Since we're now gating with newer version of oslo.utils, this
make some server package fails, so we need to bump versions of
some clients.

This update fixes the minimum version for:
- troveclient
- novaclient
- neutronclient

There may be some others to update as well.

Change-Id: Ia2ebec1b54d51b571897e42c63bd0f7b71006579
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/95/208195/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-troveclient>=1.2.0

commit_message:
Ensure anvil-job has newest six library upgraded

The built-in six library being so old causes the building
of python-cryptography into an rpm to eventually fail at build
time. To address this, make sure that the six installed is
upgraded to be the newest version (which should be safe to do
as six is very much backwards compat.).

Change-Id: I7c7468897f002bb467a78ceb1dcab2d19978c4c1
Closes-Bug: #1482696
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/07/210507/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Fix a few really old build-it system packages... # # Someday this will not be a problem... # # See: https://bugs.launchpad.net/anvil/+bug/1482696 sudo pip install six --upgrade

commit_message:
Rename os-ansible-deployment gate checks to conform to new style

This patch renames all references to dvsm-check and -check for
os-ansible-deployment to conform to the updated style used
in openstack-infra.

commit_message:
Disable venv anvil VERBOSE setting

This information is a little to verbose, and therefore not
that useful, so removing it now that the gate job works
and the information is not really needed anymore.

commit_message:
Fix the topic and server that the listener client uses

This was only working for one heat engine as it was sending
the listener messages to a topic of "engine_id".

Change-Id: Ib542d1ebb85b004f5a67213e678882c5a723dc0e
Closes-bug: 1433821
(cherry picked from commit f19c54dd9a906a538b527268b6746daa162da5ad)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/06/210606/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: topic=rpc_api.LISTENER_TOPIC) topic=rpc_api.LISTENER_TOPIC, server=lock_engine_id)

commit_message:
Move volume.api test to correct location

Test test_create_volume_with_consistencygroup_invalid_type in
tests.unit.api.v2.test_volumes is verifying consistency group
logic in cinder.volumes.api. This patch moves this test to
tests.unit.test_volume.py.

Change-Id: I0027f03fd084fd490c43e6a957f84a57de7523a6

commit_message:
Move AccessInfo objects into own module

The ServiceCatalog and ServiceProviders should not really be needed in a
standalone sense. They are there to make it easier to work with an
AccessInfo. Therefore move all of this into a standalone access module.

Change-Id: Idc6856d89c2131855657d01114cc72372b3b11f4

commit_message:
Add role_ids, role_names to v3 fixture

Commit 6950527 in python-keystoneclient added role_ids
and role_names properties to fixtures.v3.Token, and
they're used in keystoneclient unit tests, so adding
these will allow keystoneclient to switch to using
keystoneauth fixtures.

Change-Id: Ic5fa6a427a7b52d3c50b8022ac98a87f3cb630a1

added_lines: @property def role_ids(self): return [r['id'] for r in self.root.get('roles', [])] @property def role_names(self): return [r['name'] for r in self.root.get('roles', [])]

commit_message:
Remove auth/ directory

The /auth directory made sense when we were seperating the plugins from
the rest of keystoneclient, however now we are in keystoneauth there
really is no need for the auth subdirectory.

Change-Id: I94f12780af4f914ead93796a052e9dc82c6c2f81

commit_message:
Minor grammar fixes to connection pooling section

This patch resolves some of the grammatical errors and punctuation
issues in the connection pooling section of the configuration
docs.

Change-Id: Iff4ebee42b4ad444477924b0cbb5fa9e906be8e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/86/210786/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LDAP data. By default, a new connection is established for each LDAP operation. This can become highly expensive when TLS support is enabled, which is a likely configuration in an enterprise setup. Reuse of connectors from a connection pool drastically reduces overhead of initiating a new connection for every LDAPwill keep LDAP connectors alive and reused for subsequent LDAP operations. The connection lifespan is configurable as other pooling specific attributes. In the LDAP identity driver, Keystone authenticates end users via an LDAP bind with the user's DN and provided password. These kind of authentication binds can fill up the pool pretty quickly, so a separate pool is provided for end user authentication bind calls. If a deployment does not want to use a pool for those binds, then it can disable pooling selectively by setting ``use_auth_pool`` to false. If a deployment wants to use a pool for those authentication binds, then ``use_auth_pool`` needs to be set to true. For the authentication pool, a different pool size (``auth_pool_size``) and connection lifetime (``auth_pool_connection_lifetime``) can be specified. With an enabled authentication pool, its connection lifetime should be kept short so that the pool frequently re-binds the connection with the provided credentials and works reliably in the end user password change case. When ``use_pool`` is false (disabled), then the authentication pool configuration is also not used. Connection pool configuration is part of the ``[ldap]`` configuration section:
deleted_lines: LDAP data. By default, a new connection is established for LDAP operations. This can become highly expensive when TLS support is enabled which is a likely configuration in enterprise setup. Re-using of connectors from a connection pool drastically reduces overhead of initiating a new connection for every LDAPwill keep LDAP connectors alive and re-use for subsequent LDAP operations. A connection lifespan is going to be configurable with other pooling specific attributes. The change is made in LDAP handler layer logic which is primarily responsible for LDAP connection and shared common operations. In LDAP identity driver, Keystone authenticates end user by LDAP bind with user DN and provided password. These kind of auth binds can fill up the pool pretty quickly so a separate pool is provided for those end user auth bind calls. If a deployment does not want to use pool for those binds, then it can disable pooling selectively by ``use_auth_pool`` as false. If a deployment wants to use pool for those auth binds, then ``use_auth_pool`` needs to be true. For auth pool, a different pool size (``auth_pool_size``) and connection lifetime (``auth_pool_connection_lifetime``) can be specified. With enabled auth pool, its connection lifetime should be kept short so that pool frequently re-binds the connection with provided creds and works reliably in end user password change case. When ``use_pool`` is false (disabled), then auth pool configuration is also not used. Connection pool configuration is added in ``[ldap]`` configuration section:

policy) and filter by name fails, because get_objects does not use
filters and therefore, upon query by object name, the server replies
with a list of all created objects (instead of a partial list).

commit_message:
Fix get_objects to allow filtering

At the moment, an attempt to retrieve a list of objects (like qos
policy) and filter by name fails, because get_objects does not use
filters and therefore, upon query by object name, the server replies
with a list of all created objects (instead of a partial list).

Change-Id: I9df9981129b8f3b82e867c8423986f5e0150186b
Partially-Implements: blueprint quantum-qos-api

subject: Remove Ansible abstraction for Keystone
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-06 17:16:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/555d073f0554f65917cbc20041454af93f9d1985', 'message': 'Removed bootstrap.yml and start.yml abstraction

These abstractions were in place to prevent violating DRY across all
of the different services. However, they do add a layer of confusion
and complexity. I would also argue they are not best practice either.
They were a misstep on my part.

Should Ansible ever adopt a way to help us get back to following DRY
in an Ansible best-practice way, we can update the playbooks then.

Change-Id: I0daf8b78f39b919d2b88336322203f1d643fc54b

---------------------

Date:  Wed Feb 18 03:08:12 2015 +0000
Merge "Have a little fun with release notes"

Patches included with sync by file:
---------------------
base_filter.py
 - 2fbf5065 - Remove oslo.log code and clean up versionutils API
 - 5d40e143 - Remove code that moved to oslo.i18n
 - 2af88ece - Use _LI instead of _ for info message translation
 - 4a47188e - Allow filters to only run once per request if their data is static
 - fcf517d7 - Update oslo log messages with translation domains
 - cae33101 - Stop looping all filters if no objects return

base_weight.py
 - 825cb870 - Upgrade to hacking 0.10
 - a2fa4878 - Fix common.scheduler.base_weight.BaseWeigher to be Python3 compat
 - e47bc70e - Normalize Scheduler Weights

Note:  Changes were also required in cinder/scheduler/weights/capacity.py and
       cinder/scheduler/weights/volume_numper.py to change the name of the
       _weight_multiplier function to weight_multiplier so the function would
       be properly overloaded.  Additionally, a number of test cases needed to
       be updated to change the expected weights due to the addition of code
       that normalizes weights.  Last, the capacity weigher had to change from
       using float(inf) for a value to using a very large value as using
       infinity caused the normalization code to always return 0.0 for a
       a weight.

base_weight.py
 - 825cb870 - Upgrade to hacking 0.10
 - a2fa4878 - Fix common.scheduler.base_weight.BaseWeigher to be Python3 compat
 - e47bc70e - Normalize Scheduler Weights

 Note: Key changes were made that impact cinder:
   (1) The weigher base class changed the name of _weight_mulitipler() to
       weight_multiplier() which impacted cinder/scheduler/weights/capacity.py
       and cinder/scheduler/weights/volume_number.py.
   (2) Application of the weight multiplier was moved from the weigher to the
       handler and normalization of the weights prior to applying the weight
       multiplier was added.  This impacted cinder weigher test cases which
       were checking for non-normalized weights.
   (3) The normalization does not support the use of infinite weights which
       are used by the cinder capacity weigher.  When an infinite value is
       used, it is not known what the other weights will be, so this adds an
       override to CapacityWeigher for the weigh_objects() method that wraps
       the parent method to use the returned complete set of weights to
       replace any infinite weights with values that are much larger than
       the largest non-infinite weight.

Change-Id: Iad9bb431f0876e4957598c0ac0d3c8d7f67199fc

commit_message:
Sync scheduler module from oslo-incubator

The scheduler and scheduler.weights modules have not been
updated since early in the Icehouse release cycle.  This
patch brings the version in Cinder up to date with what is in
oslo-incubator.

Current HEAD in OSLO:
---------------------
commit 20d7dc57819a70abdff967299542068946d75ac1
Date:   Wed Jul 29 03:49:46 2015 +0000
    Updated from global requirements

    Change-Id: Iba0e4f9545fc9ba82f080a0fec672761dcfeaeec

Patches included with sync by file:
---------------------
base_filter.py
 - 2fbf5065 - Remove oslo.log code and clean up versionutils API
 - 5d40e143 - Remove code that moved to oslo.i18n
 - 2af88ece - Use _LI instead of _ for info message translation
 - 4a47188e - Allow filters to only run once per request if their data is static
 - fcf517d7 - Update oslo log messages with translation domains
 - cae33101 - Stop looping all filters if no objects return
 base_handler.py
 - 6fa29aee - Trivial: Make vertical white space after license header consistent
 - 35660dac7 - Enable hacking H401 test
 - 5dcc43b1 - Break out common functionality for filters and weights
base_weight.py
 - 825cb870 - Upgrade to hacking 0.10
 - a2fa4878 - Fix common.scheduler.base_weight.BaseWeigher to be Python3 compat
 - e47bc70e - Normalize Scheduler Weights

 Note: Key changes were made that impact cinder:
   (1) The weigher base class changed the name of _weight_mulitipler() to
       weight_multiplier() which impacted cinder/scheduler/weights/capacity.py
       and cinder/scheduler/weights/volume_number.py.
   (2) Application of the weight multiplier was moved from the weigher to the
       handler and normalization of the weights prior to applying the weight
       multiplier was added.  This impacted cinder weigher test cases which
       were checking for non-normalized weights.
   (3) The normalization does not support the use of infinite weights which
       are used by the cinder capacity weigher.  When an infinite value is
       used, it is not known what the other weights will be, so this adds an
       override to CapacityWeigher for the weigh_objects() method that wraps
       the parent method to use the returned complete set of weights to
       replace any infinite weights with values that are much larger than
       the largest non-infinite weight.

Change-Id: Iad9bb431f0876e4957598c0ac0d3c8d7f67199fc

commit_message:
Add iSCSI multipath support for Huawei driver

Update the Huawei18000ISCSIDriver to return lists of portals in
initialize connection instead of just choose a single one from
the list to return.

Also add _() translation markers at some place in this patch.

Co-Authored-By: Bob-OpenStack liuxinguo@huawei.com
Change-Id: I3f523a1f891e2407616a57d4507333fff45bd171
Implements: blueprint huawei-storage-iscsi-multipath-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/65/188365/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: multipath = connector.get('multipath', False) (iscsi_iqns, target_ips, portgroup_id) = \ LOG.info(_LI('initialize_connection_iscsi,iscsi_iqns: %(iscsi_iqns)s, ' 'target_ips: %(target_ips)s, ' {'iscsi_iqns': iscsi_iqns, 'target_ips': target_ips, lun = int(hostlunid) LOG.info(_LI("#####multipath#######: %s."), multipath) if not multipath: properties['target_discovered'] = False properties['target_portal'] = ('%s:%s' % (target_ips[0], '3260')) properties['target_iqn'] = iscsi_iqns[0] properties['target_lun'] = lun properties['volume_id'] = volume['id'] else: properties['target_discovered'] = False properties['target_iqns'] = [iqn for iqn in iscsi_iqns] properties['target_portals'] = [ "%s:3260" % ip for ip in target_ips] properties['target_luns'] = [lun] * len(target_ips) properties['volume_id'] = volume['id']
deleted_lines: (iscsi_iqn, target_ip, portgroup_id) = \ LOG.info(_LI('initialize_connection_iscsi,iscsi_iqn: %(iscsi_iqn)s, ' 'target_ip: %(target_ip)s, ' {'iscsi_iqn': iscsi_iqn, 'target_ip': target_ip, properties['target_discovered'] = False properties['target_portal'] = ('%s:%s' % (target_ip, '3260')) properties['target_iqn'] = iscsi_iqn properties['target_lun'] = int(hostlunid) properties['volume_id'] = volume['id']

commit_message:
Install correct crux in centos-source-base

We were picking up https://pypi.python.org/pypi/crux/ , which is not
actually the correct crux.

Change-Id: I9907a194431e36469146f733a6bb8062ea407f05
Closes-Bug: #1477481
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/77/204977/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RUN curl https://codeload.github.com/larsks/crux/tar.gz/7 -o crux.tar.gz \ && tar -xf crux.tar.gz \ && pip install /crux-7 \ && rm -rf crux.tar.gz /crux-7

commit_message:
Add py34 support in tox

This patch adds py34 support in tox.
Now few tests can be executed with the
tox command in py34 environment.

Partially-Implements: blueprint barbican-py3

Change-Id: Id92fdb2aa8e5e16eb9929e97c972e85331e20883
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/87/208787/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = pep8,py27,py34,docs[testenv:py34] deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = python -m testtools.run \ barbican.tests.common.test_utils

libvirt: convert GlusterFS driver to LibvirtBaseFileSystemVolumeDriver

Part of blueprint consolidate-libvirt-fs-volume-drivers

Change-Id: Id6ddeaa998cea7e92bd03925f39211a5d086bd47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/202780/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.virt.libvirt.volume import fsclass LibvirtGlusterfsVolumeDriver(fs.LibvirtBaseFileSystemVolumeDriver): def get_mount_point_base(self): return CONF.libvirt.glusterfs_mount_point_base self.get_device_path(connection_info)
deleted_lines: from nova.virt.libvirt.volume import volume as libvirt_volumeclass LibvirtGlusterfsVolumeDriver(libvirt_volume.LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver): def __init__(self, connection): """Create back-end to glusterfs.""" super(LibvirtGlusterfsVolumeDriver, self).__init__(connection, is_block_dev=False) def _get_device_path(self, connection_info): path = os.path.join(CONF.libvirt.glusterfs_mount_point_base, utils.get_hash_str(connection_info['data']['export'])) path = os.path.join(path, connection_info['data']['name']) return path self._get_device_path(connection_info)

commit_message:
Fix for issues in the parsing of mysql credentials.

Comments are ignored now
Force db_port to be int

Change-Id: I558901ac3a0b8e09f5272b6c995eb1de314ebdf2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/72/210272/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'instance' in line and not line.startswith("#"): if 'host' in line and not line.startswith("#"): elif 'user' in line and not line.startswith("#"): elif 'password' in line and not line.startswith("#"): elif 'port' in line and not line.startswith("#"): try: db_port = int(db_port) except ValueError: raise ValueError( logging.error('[*] MySQL port should be integer') )
deleted_lines: if 'instance' in line: if 'host' in line: elif 'user' in line: elif 'password' in line: elif 'port' in line: db_port = line.split('=')[1].strip()
